response.answer_text: I’m a bit bemused by this question and the answers so far. It is, of course, undeniable that deaf people can read. Of course they can; you don’t read with your ears… or do you? Written English is a visual representation of a spoken language.* Growing up without access to spoken English, and (this is important) without access to a signed language**, written English is always going to be difficult. Anecdotally I can say that I rarely assign reading in my classes of deaf college students because they don’t do it. They just don’t. I’ve tried and tried various ways, both carrot and stick, to get them to at least skim reading assignments, but no dice.*** Why is that? It’s because written English is still an impenetrable forest of words to too many of my students. I am hearing, and I speak, understand, and write English very well. I speak ASL fairly fluently, but no deaf people would take me for a native signer, and I have to ask for repeats when I am receiving ASL. I read French probably at a 5th grade level, speak it on a survival level, and understand almost no spoken French. I grew up using English from infancy and my two other languages I learned as an adult. Reading French is likely to continue to be a chore for me because I will never have as good a grasp on it as I do on English. And this is the case for (some of) my students. They will never be able to read or write English with the ease that many hearing people do.**** This is particularly true of students who were denied access to a genuine signed language as children. So, yes, of course deaf people can read. However, many deaf people read at a lower level than many hearing people, and many struggle with it, finding it unrewarding and more difficult than it’s worth. *More or less; a linguist will argue with me, but I think we can agree that, despite there being some different rules for written and spoken English, written English hews pretty closely to spoken English. **I mean a real signed language, not 40 signs that a hearing parent learned from Youtube. One with grammar and syntactical rules. ***To be clear, I’m painting with a broad brush here. Of course I have deaf students who read both for classes and for pleasure. Deaf people are a large and diverse group. ****Of course, I’m oversimplifying here; there are a lot of hearing native English speakers who can’t write a coherent sentence, or read past an elementary school level.

Being literate in a language you cannot speak, believe it or not, is even a “thing” among hearing people. There are countless people all over the world whose vernacular is something else, but who can read and write English even though they cannot speak it. I have encountered many people who were literate in English but did not speak it. They had been reading it for years, but in the case of most of the people I met, lived behind the iron curtain, and never had the chance to travel, so never had a chance to speak anything but their native language and Russian (because in most Communist bloc countries, it was taught in school). A few in Czechoslovakia understood German a little from picking up television broadcasts— some German in origin, some French, UK or US, dubbed in German. I point this out, because sometimes people are incredulous that Deaf people can do anything, hearing people don’t do— like learn a language they don’t speak— but when you point out that occasionally hearing people do this too, [hearing] people allow that maybe Deaf people can do it. It shouldn’t be this way, but it is. There are very few things that actually require hearing— maybe being a contestant on Name That Tune— but you see how far you have to reach to find something. FWIW, I’m sure I couldn’t be on Name That Tune either. Which was a boring show anyway. Anyway, people have been reading and writing languages they don’t speak since practically the invention of writing. Hearing people, as well as Deaf people, although given the state of Deaf ed., back when even hearing ed. was pretty much something of the 1%, being literate in a language you didn’t speak was almost entirely done by hearing people. Albeit, occasionally, you had an autodidact. It’s not necessary to know how words sound to decode them, and no, you don’t have to just memorize them. I read (although I don’t write) biblical Hebrew, but I don’t speak it. I can decode it just fine, even without the little vowel dots and dashes, but I don’t hear it in my head— not really. I see what I’m reading, it that makes sense, but pretty much, that’s how I read English too. The only time I hear words in my head is when I’m reading something like a Dorothy Parker “Constant Reader” review, but those are written to be heard, if that makes sense— you’d have to read one to know what I mean. They are written as though someone is talking to you, is the best I can do. I’m getting really tired of questions that are really a veiled “Deaf people can’t really do that, can they? I don’t get it, so it must not be true.”

Answering for myself, I was born deaf and I’m excellent with not only reading but writing too. A lot of people have a certain stigma attached to all deaf people, they can’t read. They can’t drive, the list goes on and on. But, I’ve never had the pleasure yet to even meet anyone completely deaf and that bothers me immensely. I tried to get my parents to send me to the school for the deaf where I’d have fit in perfectly. But I was mainstreamed into the hearing world all through my school years. I got either fair to flunking certain classes because so much of the material was tested on us using the teachers voice to talk to the class. However, I thank my lucky stars that my 5th and 6th grade teacher took me under my wing while making the class do assignments while she was teaching me everything I needed to know about the English language. I went on to win spelling bees, I got straight A’s in English only. All the teachers on other subjects never took such an interest in me to make sure I understood everything in his/her class, therefore, I barely passed, meaning I got lucky enough to graduate from high school. The reason I begged from time to time was because back in those days, kids teased and bullied me on a daily basis, and as a result, I always had a knot in my stomach each morning I went to school. I don’t sign, never learned it because reading lips is how I learned to “hear”. I got off topic here, but the bottom line really is it depends on the person whether they’re deaf or not. Since I was excellent in my English class, and still excell in English all these days later, I am starting on a book, an autobiography on myself. As of now, before I really get started good, the title of my book is planned to be ““Growing Up Deaf in a Hearing World.” I am hoping to not eliminate most all stigmas on the deaf but to also educate those who want to know about them, parents who have their first and only experience with a deaf child and hopefully use what they read in my book to make the best decision in whether they need to send their child to the Scool of the Deaf. Did I say I only got straight A’s in English? Imagine what difference my grades would’ve been had I gone to the special school for the deaf. To answer your question on if Deaf people can read? What is the difference between deaf people that cannot read vs. hearing people who can’t read? That is a thought for you to think about. Each person in our life is different, Deaf or hearing or blind.

“Can deaf people read?” Of course they can. It would have been awfully difficult for my deaf friends who have doctoral degrees to write their dissertations if they didn’t know how to read and write. It would have been awfully difficult for my deaf friends who have driver’s licenses to pass their driving tests if they didn’t know how to read. If would have been awfully difficult for my deaf friends who are lawyers to pass their bar examinations if they didn’t know how to read and write. If would be awfully difficult for my deaf friends who are gourmet cooks to figure out what a recipe says if they didn’t know how to read. What on earth gave you the idea that you need to be able to hear as a prerequisite to reading? Final note: I’m hearing, and I don’t hear sounds in my head when I read a book. I’m an unusually fast reader. Cruising speed for me is about 1,000 words per minute. There’s no way on earth I would be able to process written text at a speed like that if I translated the material I was reading into sounds in my head.

Can deaf/mute people read? If you think about it they've never heard a sound nor can they create one. When you read you hear it in your head. Oh, goodness. Where to start? Deaf people cannot hear. The majority of them are not mute. Mute people cannot use their voice. The majority of them are not deaf. Deafness and muteness are two entirely different, completely unrelated things. Deaf people who were born 100% deaf have never heard a sound, that much is true. They might not use their voice very often, but they are quite capable of making sounds come out of their mouths. Not everyone who is deaf is 100% deaf. Not everyone who is deaf was born that way. Perhaps you hear it in your head when you read, but that’s only because that’s how you learned it. Written words evoke mental words, but sound is not required to have words.

Sigh. I’ve been awake since about 3 in the morning so I’m not going to even address the “mute” thing. Too tired for that. I’m Deaf. I have a Ph.D., which I believe requires a little bit of literacy. But then again, who knows, in today’s world…..? But instead of proving my ability to read and write with or without sound, I’ll just direct you to a paper I’ve written on the topic which explains basically, that sound is NOT important for reading. If you want to know how and why, then prove YOUR literacy by reading it: Why Shouldn't Sam Read? Toward a New Paradigm for Literacy and the Deaf.

Question: Can deaf/mute people read? If you think about it they've never heard a sound nor can they create one. When you read you hear it in your head. My answer: Deaf and mute people only need eyes to read. Well everyone needs eyes for reading. Mute people can still hear…. And read too…. So that's kinda unnecessary to ask if they can read. Deaf people can read (see below how I learnt to read) and create sounds from their mouths. Therefore we Deaf people can visualise sounds in our heads. In fact, I learnt to read by learning my native language first then match the alphabet to those letters you see in English. If you don't understand what I'm saying just before so basically, I learnt my native language then the English language then match them up to understand what I'm reading/saying.

I recently had a conversation on this very subject with a coworker who is an English teacher. She told me me that my ability to speak and write was remarkable for someone who was Deaf, and asked how I was able to develop those skills. I told her that a lot of Deaf people are good at giving presentations and good at writing. They just have crappy teachers who assume they can’t read or write. It is more difficult for people who are hearing to teach Deaf people how to read and write, because they tend to adopt techniques that favor hearing people, and look upon being deaf as some sort of deficit, when it isn’t.

Yes, they very much can. While most people read out loud in their head, this is not actually a necessary part of read. My sister, for example, started to learn how to read before it was properly taught to her, and so she never really learned phonics. This means that when she reads, she doesn’t hear the words in her head, she just takes it in. Because of this, she is a very fast reader. Once she read an inch thick graphic novel of mine in about 15 minutes.

I think that it depends on your surroundings as well as your upbringing. I have not had to much problem in my reading and writing, although I am a HUGE fan of auto-correct. Why I say that is because although I do speak quite regularly and most people do not know that I am Deaf, I do say many words incorrectly. Being a published author (OK, I was 12 when a story I wrote won a young author conference award) and an avid reader, I think this helps a lot. I read four different newspapers each morning: The New York Times, the Seattle Times, Britain’s Daily Telegraph, and the Irish Independent. Each puts a little different twist on the news and I feel that I get a better perspective on what is going on from these four different angles. I also read 8–10 books a month. I tend to read two personal growth books to one entertainment book. So, to answer your question, “Is it more difficult for deaf people to read and write”, my answer would be no. It all matters on how you perceive your environment. How you react to it, and if you are willing to put effort into it. I do feel that their are more stumbling blocks to leap over when you are Deaf, but if you are willing to put the work in, you will be set to go!

Yes, they can. They can actually do a lot more than people think. Deaf people can read, write, go out on their own without an interpreter, drive, ride a motorcycle, even listen to music (they turn it up really loud to feel the vibrations).

Well, you’re talking about two different groups of people. Mute people can hear. So that doesn’t apply. They read exactly the same way non-mute people read. Deaf people who were born deaf read without hearing it in their heads. They are visual by nature, so they see it in their heads or they translate it to sign language in their heads.

Actually, I excelled at reading and writing. Television wasn’t closed captioned when I was a kid so reading was the best way to take in a story without missing anything. Writing was an outlet because I couldn’t speak well. My mother was a school teacher and she read to me all the time, starting before she knew I couldn’t hear. She pointed out words as she read and I learned to read lips as she did so. Therefore, I was able to make the connection and learned to read before I entered first grade at the age of five:
Can people that are deaf read? Why of course if they’ve been taught just like anyone that is hearing. Deafness doesn’t prohibit reading, writing, driving a car, or traveling.

With their eyes, which generally speaking work far better than their ears. Of course, they don’t whisper out loud to themselves as they read—as might be the case with *some people* who ask silly questions on Quora—but other than that they read just like hearing people read.
